text: - [HAL 9000] Dave.
Stop.
I've still got the greatest enthusiasm
and confidence in the mission.
And I want to help you.
(dramatic music)
- [Vashi] I've never told anyone like
the secret sauce for it.
I use DaVinci Resolve.
I'll do Auto Scene Detection.

It'll find every edit
point and create a cut.
And I pick what I consider the best frame.

The poster frame, it's
the meat of the shot,
or that iconic thing.
And then I have this representation

of a film with all of its
individual components.
I can see color pallets,
I can see editing pace, tempo,
I can see so much.
That birds-eye view of being able to
poke around in the innards.
Why does this scene work so well?

And see what the other
editors have decided.
What the other directors did to make
something successful.

- [Sven] He's the guy
who made a video essay

on the center framing
in Mad Max: Fury Road.
He's the guy who consulted on the editing
workflow of Gone Girl
- [Woman] ...kill your wife Nick?
- [Sven] and Deadpool.

He's also the guy that
cut 11 Hollywood films
including the classic, Sharknado 2.
(dramatic music)
Inducted in 2018 by
the American Cinema Editor Society,

Vashi Nedomansky, ACE
is the guy who created

the Seven Commandments to
Become a Better Editor.
(thunder clap)
(ringing)
- [Sven] Hello?
- [Vashi] Hey I got, we got disconnected.
- Yeah that's weird
- Weird
- You're still rolling right?
- I'm still rolling I didn't cut.
- Okay so it shouldn't be a problem.
All right so number 1 is

Watch every frame of raw
footage at least twice,
then start.
- [Vashi] I think the only way to become

comfortable with the
footage is to watch it.

I'll sit there for 4 hours
watching it real time.
None of this 2 time shit.

The first time is literally
just a visceral experience,
just to let it wash over you.

The second time I'll
make notes and markers
and pay attention more to everything else.
You have to live that footage,
before you can start editing.
If you just go to circle takes
and start building a scene,
you're doing a huge disservice,
not only to yourself, but to the film,
the director, to the actors, to everyone.
- [Sven] The big thing is, and what I find
a lot of beginning editors do,
they see one thing, and they're like,
'Oh I know how to cut the scene!'
And they just start working on it.
- [Vashi] Yeah.
- [Sven] And they're sort of then just
cutting themselves into a corner.
- [Vashi] I agree completely.
I mean, I feel getting there and becoming

so familiar with
everything is the only way
I can approach a scene.
(video playing)
- [Baz Luhrmann] Go on and cut more,

cut more baby. How can
you improve the film?
Improve the film!

- [Sven] Nurture the
relationship with a director.
It's sacred.

- [Vashi] It's literally
an editor and a director

in a room for 6 months,
9 months, 10 months.
Together all day long.
- [Jill Bilcock] He is a magician
because he hypnotizes you into
nothing else matters.
(laughs)
And he gets it done.
(car screeching)
- [Vashi] You have to be positive.

Like, if you're negative,
then the director
is going to be negative.

Then the focus changes from
working on the story to,
'Why is my editor being grumpy?
What the fuck's going on?'

- [Man] All right you
do it then. Just do it.
- [Woman] Just take a step back.

- [Vashi] You have to
assume the role of that
secondary person in the relationship.
And try and find solutions
and offer up different ways to look at it.
Being calm, being soothing.

Make it a place the
director wants to be in.
You just have to create like a little nest
for the two of you to work in.
And the sooner you can learn that,

then the longer, I think,
your career will be.
- [Sven] What are some specifics that
a beginning editor can do to, like,
start off on a good note with a director?

- [Vashi] Get the intent
of the film early.
If you're meeting with the director,
even if you're just doing a short film.
Get reference points.

Say, 'What kind of
films are you going for?
What kind of tones?'
So if the director is like,
'I want it to be like Heat.
I want it to be really, you know, broody
and cinematic and huge.'
(gunshots)

That's great! You know,
you know what that is.
If they say

'Oh, I want it to be
like French Connection.

I just want it to be
gritty, hand-held, grimy.'
That's a whole other set of notes.
(gunshot)

- [Sven] It does happen that
they bring up certain movies.
And if I haven't seen them,
I just sort of quietly write them down.
- [Vashi] Oh, yeah!
- [Sven] And make sure that the next time,
I better have seen that movie because

that's the language that
the director is using.

- [Will Ferrell] It's
like a scene from that
one movie. I always forget the name of it.
(snapping)
Uh, with Meg Ryan.

- [Mark Wahlberg] I don't
remember a movie where

Meg Ryan meets a guy with
poison ivy up his ass.
- [Will Ferrell] I'll think of it
- [Sven] Find any shot instantly.
Organization is paramount.
- [Vashi] Oh, God. This is the one thing
that I've seen with young editors.
Organize your work flow in your system

so you can literally find
any shot at any second.
When the director comes in, they say,

- [Leonardo DiCaprio]
Yeah. Run reel 10 again.
I think we're duplicating the shot here.

- [Vashi] You gotta have like
2 clicks and you're there.
All this work about organization.
All this talk about it.
It is all done at the beginning.
And all that time spent early,
downstream will save you.
Especially on a future film when you're
dealing with hundreds of hours of footage.
- [Sven] Yep.
- [Vashi] You're gonna be fatigued,
you're gonna be tired.
So you have to have this system that

even when you're exhausted,
you can get there
and find something and show it right away.

Directors hate to wait when
you're looking for clips.
They're like, 'Nope. That's not the shot.'
And you're like 'I, I, I know,
I'm just trying to get to the area.'
Then you're not organized.
- [Robert De Niro] One of these days
I'm gonna get organizized.
- [Cybill Shepherd] You mean organized?
- [Sven] Number 4.
Factor in extra time for renders,
exports, errors, and crashes.

- [Vashi] As an editor,
there are certain things

that are out of your hands
that you can't plan for.
And when people say,
'Oh, I need this by, whatever, this time'

And you think the render
is gonna be an hour.
- [Mr. Incredible] Yeah I've got time.

- [Vashi] Sometimes
you have to stop early,

and get the thing going
earlier than you expect,

because you have to plan
for some kind of mess up.
- [Man] Expect the unexpected

- [Vashi] I remember
once for the documentary

I had to send a blu-ray
to South By Southwest.
So, I'm burning the blu-ray,
and I just quickly scanned it.
I made sure the menu came up.
And then I FedExed it overnight.
The next day the director was like,

'Yep, fired up the blu-ray
and the menu comes on,
but the main feature doesn't play.'

And they had to show,
like, the previous version.

And I absolutely goat
fucked the screening.
(goats bleating)
And that's on me.

And as a professional I just
wanted to disappear forever.
Like that's fireable.
- [Man] We fucked up.
- [Vashi] That's a fireable offense.
You can try and explain yourself,
and you'll just hear,
- [Arnold Schwarzenegger] You're fired.
(missile launching)
- [Vashi] So you have to say,

earlier in the day, 'I'm
gonna be done at noon,

I'm stopping editing and
I'm starting the exports,
the renders, all the other stuff.
- [Sven] All right. Number 5.
Attempt edits that shouldn't work.
You'll be surprised.
- [Steve Carell] You know when they say,
'It's so crazy it just might work'?

- [Vashi] As an editor,
you have all the footage,

you're cutting stuff, you're
making your decisions.
You feel like you're driving the bus.
You're the...

- [Man] King of the
castle. King of the castle.

- [Vashi] No one knows it
better than you. Right?
I've tried every way to do this,
I've done this, I've cut the scene 6 ways,
there's no way it could be any better.
Wrong!
- [Man] 27 apple, take 2
- [Director] Action.
- [Vashi] You can't look at 2 shots
and understand what they mean together.
- [Woman] Why the pout?
- [Man] Would that, it were so simple.
- [Director] Cut.
(bell ringing)
- [Vashi] Everything is adjustable.

Everything is changeable.
Everything is malleable.
End up being much better than what I had.

And until you physically
do it, and see it,
and watch it, you won't know.
- [Woman] Why the pout?
- [Vashi] And I'm constantly surprised.
- [Man] It's
complicated.
- [Vashi] By things that should not work
end up being much better than what I had.

- [David Fincher] When you
set out to make a movie,

it doesn't happen exactly the
way you have it in your head.

There is this exploration.
There is this evolution.

There is this unfolding, or
revealing of the material.
- [Man] I'm left handed.

My teachers tried to
make me when I was a kid,
but I couldn't.
- [Sven] Spend more time on audio.
It's the glue of your edit.
(electric guitar blasting)
- [Vashi] Oh my God! This is so awesome.
I worked with Billy Fox.
And he takes his middle monitor,
it's only the timeline.

And at the top, he has
like, 3 tracks of video.
And underneath, 36 tracks of audio.

It's a cliche by now, but
audio saves everything.

And I'm not talking about
putting needle drops
or songs to cover stuff.

I'm talking about having
a immersive, fluid,
seamless audio underneath the picture.
(monster roars)
Even the simplest thing of like,

having the dissolves on
all the lines of dialogues
so there's no clicks or pops.

What I do is I apply,
you know, like a 2 frame
cross dissolve on the front and back
(click)

Cross dissolve on the front
and back of every clip.
It's so minor. It's like one frame. Click.
(meteors crashing)
But, that's all you'll hear in the room.

- [Sven] That's something
I learned the hard way.

Because I was working on a
tv show with some editors,
and every time you deliver a cut
and there's a click or a pop in there

that means you have to
pay drinks that night.
- [Woman] He's buying!
(crowd cheers)
- [Vashi] Absolutely!
When I was playing professional hockey,
there's 23 guys in the bus,
and the bus leaves at 6A.M.

If you come down at 6:04, the
bus does not wait for you.

And on top of that, you're
buying dinner for the team.

They literally get the
menu they go to the waiter,
'Uh, just bring me the most expensive item

on the menu.' They don't
even care what it is.

They just wanna bury you,
and teach you a lesson.
And then you're never late for that
6 'O' clock bus ever again.
- [Sven] All right last one, number 7.
Cut for the scene,
but always in context to the whole film.
- [Vashi] You have to have a macro

and a micro view of the
whole film at all times.
So when I'm cutting the scene,

I'm focused on the scene
but in the back of my head
I'm always thinking, 'how is this laying
in the story compared to everything that's
happening before or after?'

And I know that every edit
affects the whole film.
When I'm focusing on 2 shots,
and then adding a 3rd shot and 4th shot,
I'm making sure that works for me.

But I'm also saying, 'Is
the tone of this scene

completely out of wack
with everything else
in this picture?'

- [Nicolas Cage] What are
these fucking iguanas doing
on my coffee table?
- [Vashi] So it's birds eye view,
and then also zoomed in all the way
to the microscopic level.

You have to be balancing
that at all times.
And just trying to keep perspective
by going micro and macro.
But that's, yeah, that's the last one.
But if you don't advance yourself

and become a better
editor and a better person

every day. And a better
film maker, on top of that,
then you'll be in it for the short run,
but you won't have a long career.
(upbeat music)
Thanks for watching.
(upbeat music)
